title: How is life better now than 50 years ago? - Quora

response.answer_text: I was 12. Fifty years ago. We didn't lock the door, we slept with all the windows open. The basement door was always left open. Sometimes our friends would get locked out of the house ,if they didn't make curfew . So we left the door open so they could sleep in the red room. Political parties weren't trying to start another Civil war. We had antenna TV. We only had 5 channels to watch. We had a house phone,and phone booths on almost every corner. No computers. We spent most of time outside, riding bikes. Playing in the woods. Climbing trees. Or just going for walks. Vietnam War was going on. 5 college kids were killed by the National Guard protesting the war at Michigan State University. No car phones, or cell phones. Cigarettes were 25 cents a pack, our weekly grocery shopping was 25 dollars . A phone call from a phone booth was a dime. Bottles of soda were a dime each. Movie theater tickets were 50 cents. Civil rights movement was just starting to grow stronger, feminist movement was just starting. Bobby Kennedy was asassinated, so was reverend Martin Luther King. Then all hell broke loose. After they both died. I started marching for peace, Civil rights. President Johnson was in office. He started gradually pulling our boys out of Vietnam. We had respect for adults. We ate meals together as a family. We had record players not stereos, in our rooms. FM radio stations were just becoming popular. The politics were alot more civilized. Smear campaigns hardly ever happened. There was censorship on the TV and radio stations. Nobody was allowed to use foul language on any shows or the radio. Richard Nixon became president. And a few years later was impeached. For Watergate. I could go on forever, but I'll stop here. Hope you enjoyed reminiscing with me. One more thing, the original Star Trek was on TV. Thanks for reading this. May god bless you all.

I was born in the United States, so my perspective is focused there. Fifty years ago: Children could play outside without minute-by-minute parental supervision. That isn't to say that kids were safe, but before both parents had to go to work just to maintain a decent standard of living, there were enough mothers at home to keep tabs on children playing. Maybe that is why horrible crimes against children happened considerably less often, or perhaps society simply hung together better then. My personal belief is that creeping income inequality has had much to do with the social unrest now threatening to upset what is left of order in my nation. The battles for racial equality, social and wage parity for women, an end to U.S. military involvement all over what was then called the Third World, and other fractures to peace and justice were raging. But fifty years ago, it looked as if a majority of the nation was beginning to choose the side of compassion and non-violence. A wave of assassinations had swept over the nation in response to the changes. Then yet another self-aggrandizing criminal set himself the task (or so the official record states) of killing Martin Luther King, Jr., the country's best-known proponent of non-violence and social justice. Somehow it all began to unravel on a hundred different domestic fronts from there. Violence is the birthright and chief perversion of many of the societies founded in the European rush to colonize the world, not just this society. You know the story. Indigenous peoples were dispossessed and decimated by contagious diseases in many parts of the globe. Slavery was the chief method of manufacturing wealth in the New World for too long a time. Up until very recent years, the government of the United States has been relatively stable, while the society was prone to internecine mayhem and murder: racially-based oppression that went beyond localized Jim Crow laws to include Jews and immigrants of Asian origin, lynchings, the rather late arrival of voting rights for women (1920, less than a hundred years ago) and some minorities, and on and, sadly, on. The penchant for using violence to “solve” disputes puzzles me as much as anyone. We now have a Federal government presided over by another self-aggrandizing individual who admires fascists and seems entirely ignorant of our Constitution and our history. I fear that everything that has gone wrong here will continue to grow worse. Certainly children are not safe in public places, parents often must work multiple jobs to keep the rent paid, incidents of hate crimes of various derivations have increased, and those of us who have struggled for decades on unfairly low wages go into old age fearing stunning levels of poverty and deprivation. There is no need for a border wall on our southern border. Once they learn the new realities of my country, who's going to want to come here? We still have the Constitutionally-guaranteed right to speak our minds--non-violently--and to protest. As long as we use those rights to keep the ship of state from sinking to the bottom of “the swamp”, I have hope. But some of my fellow citizens are fighting tooth and claw to stay in a past that never was what they believe they remember. If a fascist government is the price of unlocked doors, personal “safety”, and order by law, the price is too high.

Better now: Personal hygiene,Personal pocket computers (smartphones) with ability to instantly recall any information (little good it has done to us though), entertain to no end, help with many areas of your life, keeping your organised, …… and of course our phones can connect us anywhere, to anyone, on a whim for mere pennies.Much better cars (never ever getting lost with the SatNav; shiny outsides and plush insides; much, much cleaner — no stench at all; and safer; the dashboards feature virtually ultramodern technology with lots of information for the driver, never boring to drive), — instead of being stinky, clunky, dirty, unreliable, requiring constant maintenance and knowledge of mechanical labour, and only having a boring speedo, petrol gauge and water temperature gauge.In general we now have much more respect to environment and do much more recycling instead of multiplying the landfills. (Me, likes).Much better medicine (we really know much more about our health now, I still shudder when I recall a root canal extraction done to me with arsenicum anesthesia in 80’s…), and most people here in Britain do not smoke anymore, cigs are nearly banned,Computer-based weather forecasts, which are just a tad bit more accurate :)Life is generally much easier for lazy people (internet entertainment, instant books, movies, food deliveries, Amazon, lots of people at your service to do anything — but people pay for this by becoming bloated and even obese…).Disabled people are no longer confined to their homes — they are now just “differently abled”.LGBT people are no longer persecuted in First World countries.You can live almost without carrying any cash around, so aren’t afraid of robberies usually. You pay with small plastic cards or even the touch of your phone.The Earth is now really small due to cheap air travel. We can go anywhere on Earth for our holiday without being ultra rich. Europe is like our own backyard. We can experience things we previously usually only could read about (And get disappointed about them, too… Remember “To See Paris and Die”? — well, there’s nothing to die for anymore.)More ways to become rich without toiling for decades.Better then: Life with much less stressing factors and much higher overall personal security. My Mom and Dad could have one career and have jobs for life and retire comfortably at 55 and 60 correspondingly (I’ll probably have to wait until I’m 68 or even 70…).The pace of life was very steady and not too fast at all. So lots of time for: being outdoors, gatherings and parties, chatting and drinking, pursuing hobbies.There was more luxury in certain areas for those endowed with money. Private clubs. Chauffeurs, cooks and butlers. Opulent balls and receptions. Several dressing levels.Airlines were decent places to be while flying: more leg space, more luxury, better food, more included. Cost more, too, though :)A small bit of concentrated effort could put you in front of so big a percentage of people (you knew a host of Karate moves and weren’t afraid of any bullies… today you better study something advanced).Discipline in schools and at work — people knew where to be serious and where to let their hair down, as a result, services worked better.People worked locally, bought locally, lived locally a lot. Less pollution, more walking and using public transport.World was a bit safer back then. Globalisation today makes the world cantankerous and prone to explosions. More information available publicly today often just makes things worse than 50 years ago; people keep worrying about a lot of things far outside of their Sphere of Influence, things they can’t change at all, — so more information is just keeping them unduly stressed and brings them no benefit.Sun was brighter, songs better, girls prettier, life easier, sex more enjoyable :) — but then this last one may or may not exactly be true — you be the judge :))

Contrary to the opinion of some; We're nowhere near as close to a Third World War as we were in the past.There are faaarrrr fewer wars and people dying from them, then in the past 100 years, if not longer.The ability to communicate with someone else on the other side of the world is still unique. Sure,it's abused and mistreated, but for the average person just to debate another forigener about events is astounding.Technology. I was actually hesitant to add this because there are certain aspects that I totally disdain, but overall, I think it's still been a major accomplishment.Communism, for all intent and purposes, is gone.I truly think some ways of the past are going by the wayside, especially rascists. It's hard to contemplate because just about any incident today is “so in your face” in part because of technology, but at the end of the day, we're trying to correct a centuries old problem in such a short period of time and have made gigantic strides. Maybe not as big as some, but compared to the 60's? Are you kidding me?The same can finally be said of the LGBT community. Just like minorities, many lost their freedom and lives to get to this point and again, while far from perfect, look at how different it was 25yrs ago.People are becoming just as excited in outer world exploration, similar to how it was 50yrs ago. We're not quite on even keel with the 1960s yet, but we're getting there, despite the lack off real possibility of going to another world anytime soon. People are starting to embrace exploring again.We're certainly aware of our surroundings. We know how we damage our world and again, we're trying to solve a century's old problem in a short time frame, but we're making strides. How many recilcle buckets were around in the 1960s?We're advancing. We can't always see it because we have both a lack of patience as well as being short-sighted at times, but we're advancing.

Well, when my mother was 6 years old in Houston, she was allowed to ride the trolley downtown by herself because there would be lots of adults to help her. The idea anyone would do her harm never entered anyone’s mind. When I was a child, we didn’t lock our doors or our cars. Every parking lot had a truck with unlocked guns on the rack, and windows down, and no one bothered them. A girl I wen to high school with posted a high school beach party picture on Facebook and commented, “There was no fear, just no fear”, in the early 70’s. In the 80’s crime went up with immigration, but gays and minorities became generally accepted, and the top Democrats noticed they were started to lose their racism franchise. Then in the 90’s they started really playing up racism in their media outlets, which became progressively difficult to maintain with all the successful blacks running around. After Barrack got elected, and reelected, the divisive media effort became intense, the average person never sees racism in their daily lives, so intense media pressure is essential for “racism” survive as “thing”. We had hate a spate of fake hate crimes because real ones are so hard to find. Invisible racism was invented with “unconscious bias” and “micro aggressions”. There are 167 female college graduates for every 100 males, yet females claim to be oppressed. Is giving even one male an educational or employment opportunity evidence of systematic, institutional oppression? White males already have a 250% greater suicide rate than black males, and far greater than females. Do we all have to kill ourselves to satisfy their greed and need to blame their short comings on someone else? Maybe Political Correctness is just a cover for petty ego and sadistic cruelty? If we are to follow Dr. King and “Judge by the content of character” how should they individuals be rated? There has been celebrating in streets for months over George Floyd, but there isn’t any evidence that racially motivated, not personal or just cruel. No racist comments were recorded, and the cop worked at minority club for 10 years. Hard to believe he would have kept that job if was going around being racist. Democrat’s Prayer We thank thee, O Lord, for Donald John Trump, who has come to deliver Democrats in the Winter of Our Discontent. Robbed of racism, with no one to hate or demean, we suffered a terrible emptiness. We praise You for the Supporters of Trump. Legions we can demonize for the sweet rush of sanctimonious self-righteousness, in the name of love, and inclusion, and fellowship for all. Now and forever, we are delivered from personal responsibility, the need to do our part, as we cast our sins upon Donald John Trump, who suffers for our souls. Amen For me, the 60’s were far safer, friendlier, more innovative, and more inclusive. The Civil Rights Act of 1964 got passed for a reason, people were ready for it.

Fifty years ago I was eleven. So this basically means, for me, “how has the world changed in your lifetime?” Most of what I observe is relatively local, not necessarily global, but it may have value none the less. People who are not of the same race or ethnic group can now be friends and family. Likewise people not heterogeneous sexually. Religion and science became enemies, but are now becoming friends again. What happens around the world is recognized as relevant to the whole world. Sometimes. Global war does not seem so imminent. Smaller scale war is everywhere and is, regretably, of lesser emotional impact to those not part of it. We have become accustomed to the same news stories with different names. I have had to live through several incarnations of the fashions of the 1970′s. This seems unfair, and unlikely to change. More information (and misinformation) is available everywhere and sorting it out is difficult. Some folks have stopped trying. People left the cities for suburbs and even rural areas, and now are moving back to cities. Technology has brought us all together and also keeps us apart. (I am posting words that may be read by someone on the other side of the world, but I don't know the names of the children down the road. They probably stay indoors and play video games.) Animals still expect and need to be fed, only now I am going out to feed the peacocks as well as the dog and cats. This change is good.

50 years ago I was watching "Leave it to Beaver" on our black and white TV, playing kickball, teasing little girls, riding my bike wherever I wanted without fear, going to the skating rink, building paper airplanes and boats, and all the little things we made up to do. I watched the Ed Sullivan Show and saw some guys called The Beatles who I didn't quite understand, but they were cool. I am thinking how nice things were back in 1964 and having trouble coming up with reasons why life is better now. Kids don't have to crawl under their desks for a nuclear war drill I guess. I don't know much about grownup things in 1964, I was a kid. I am not a kid now, and mine are grown, so I don't know much about how it is for kids now as compared to then. For me, I guess it is a matter of innocence. I had it in 1964, but I had to search for it again in later years. I don't really know if that makes life today better, but I am glad I remember some of what is was like 50 years ago. I'm glad for everything I remember because that makes life today better than it would be without it.

1969. The first manned landing on the Moon (Apollo 11). The creation of the internet. The commencement of the Gay Rights Movement. Led Zeppelin and Led Zeppelin II, the first two Led Zeppelin albums, were released in the United States. Martial law was declared in Madrid, as the University is closed and over 300 students are arrested. An explosion aboard the aircraft carrier USS Enterprise near Hawaii killed 27 and injured 314. The Soviet Union launched Venera 5 and 6 and Soyuz 4 and 5. Nixon was sworn in. A blowout on Union Oil's Platform A spilled 80,000 to 100,000 barrels of crude oil into a channel and onto the beaches of Santa Barbara County in Southern California; on February 5 the oil spill closed Santa Barbara's harbor. The incident inspired Wisconsin Senator Gaylord Nelson to organize the first Earth Day in 1970. The Beatles gave their last public performance. The Allende meteorite exploded over Mexico. The Boeing 747 "jumbo jet" was flown for the first time, taking off from the Boeing airfield at Everett, Washington. The Mariner 6 Mars probe was launched by the United States. The US undertook Operation Breakfast, the covert bombing of Cambodia. Dwight D. Eisenhower died. Dr. Denton Cooley implanted the first temporary artificial heart. The Harvard University Administration Building was seized by nearly 300 students, mostly members of the Students for a Democratic Society. Robin Knox-Johnston became the first person to sail around the world solo nonstop. The Battle of Dong Ap Bia, also known as Hamburger Hill, commenced. An American teenager known as 'Robert R.' died in St. Louis, Missouri, of a baffling medical condition much later identified as the earliest confirmed case of HIV/AIDS in North America. United States National Guard helicopters sprayed skin-stinging powder on anti-war protesters in California. The National Convention of the Students for a Democratic Society, held in Chicago, collapsed and the Weatherman faction seized control of the SDS National Office. Thereafter, any activity run from the National Office or bearing the name of SDS was Weatherman-controlled. The Cuyahoga River fire helped spur an avalanche of water pollution control activities resulting in the Clean Water Act, Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement and the creation of the federal Environmental Protection Agency. Judy Garland died of a drug overdose. Vietnam War: The very first U.S. troop withdrawals were made. The United States' $500, $1,000, $5,000 and $10,000 bills were officially withdrawn from circulation. Chappaquiddick incident – Edward M. Kennedy drove off a bridge on his way home from a party on Chappaquiddick Island, Massachusetts. Mary Jo Kopechne, a former campaign aide to his brother, diee in the early morning hours of July 19 in the submerged car. John Fairfax landed in Hollywood Beach, Florida near Miami and became the first person to row across an ocean solo, after 180 days spent at sea on board 25' ocean rowboat 'Britannia' (left Gran Canaria on January 20). Violence erupted after the Apprentice Boys of Derry march in Derry, Northern Ireland, resulting in a three-day communal riot known as the Battle of the Bogside. British troops were deployed. Woodstock. No further explanation needed. Category 5 Hurricane Camille, the most powerful tropical cyclonic system at landfall in history, hit the Mississippi coast, killing 248 people and causing US$1.5 billion in damage (1969 dollars). The first automatic teller machine in the United States was installed in Rockville Centre, New York. Lieutenant William Calley was charged with six counts of premeditated murder for the 1968 My Lai Massacre deaths of 109 Vietnamese civilians in My Lai, Vietnam. Scooby-Doo aired its first episode on the CBS network in the United States. The very last theatrical Warner Bros. cartoon was released: the Merrie Melodies short Injun Trouble. The Brady Bunch was broadcast for the first time on ABC. Monty Python's Flying Circus first aired on BBC One. Days of Rage: In Chicago, the Illinois National Guard was called in to control demonstrations involving the radical Weathermen, in connection with the "Chicago Eight" Trial. Fourteen black athletes were kicked off the University of Wyoming football team for wearing black armbands into their coach's office. Wal-Mart incorporated as Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. Pink Floyd released their Ummagumma album. A group of American Indians, led by Richard Oakes, seized Alcatraz Island as a symbolic gesture, offering to buy the property for $24 from the U.S. government. Sesame Street aired its first episode on the NET network. Vietnam War: In Washington, D.C., 250,000–500,000 protesters staged a peaceful demonstration against the war, including a symbolic "March Against Death". Regular colour television broadcasts began on BBC1 and ITV in the United Kingdom. Cold War: Negotiators from the Soviet Union and the United States met in Helsinki, to begin the SALT I negotiations aimed at limiting the number of strategic weapons on both sides. Vietnam War: The first draft lottery in the United States since World War II was held. The Boeing 747 jumbo jet made its first passenger flight. Invention of Unix under the potential name "Unics" (after Multics). The Second-generation Dodge Challenger automobile was introduced in the United States. Women were allowed membership in the Future Farmers of America (the later National FFA Organization).

Better 50 years ago: There was $0 tuition in all of the colleges of CUNY, the unions were much stronger, my country (the U.S.) did not have over 80 military bases overseas, the climate was not threatening us with extinction, the use of nuclear weapons was apparently still considered to be avoided at all costs, our oceans were not choking on plastic waste, the Supreme Court had not yet crippled the ability of swindled people to sue by validating the widespread use of arbitration agreements and severely limiting class actions, and every day did not bring news of some new outrageous actions by our President, Congress and Supreme Court, and some state governments. What is better now: with all the upswing in racism and sexism many, many more Americans are really against such filth, the mainstream media has been exposed, especially by Wikileaks, as a tool of government not our watchdogs, and our governments being mostly tools of very large corporations, but with all the upswing in corporate exploitation of the public, the decreasing acceptance of a diseased profit system form of economics.

I was only 8 yrs old then, so what I know is what was told to me. It was truly the best of times and the worst of times. For one thing there was no internet. That in itself would be enough to make some people want to go back into time and stay. Now maybe the info I was told was based solely on the people that they knew at the time. It may or may not be the same for those that did not live in my home state or hometown. Most people actually worked for a living, the work may not have always been glamorous in fact some work was probably very shitty work. But they knew they had to support their family, and they did the work. People were too busy trying to make a living than to concern themselves with that person that said fuck or shit while they were going to wherever they were going. People pretty much minded their own business, and let people be themselves, talk the way they were going to talk. Hey I was doing research on that era in time for something I was going to write. This much I do remember: Kids could go outside and play way after dark. But in our case dad did not like us going to the local park without an adult. He was a cop and had those he had arrested looking for a chance to get even. But in our neighborhood neighbors watched out for the kids. If someone didn’t look like they belonged in the neighborhood the people would call the cops. Yeah all this leads up to: The people were different back then. That made it a lot better than here and now. Some people were very kind and good natured. Some were real assholes. Hehe. I remember one asshole that was bitching because we were walking down the street with a football, We were going to the school that was just a few short blocks away. Me being me I wised off. I had said the immortal words that have become my trademark all these years later. I was 8 years old and I said: “GO FUCK YOURSELF.” He yelled: “What did you just say to me?” I repeated myself. A neighbor heard it all called the police knowing my dad would probably answer the call. In the meantime the creep demanded to know my parents names. “Mom and Dad.” He was getting madder. “NO! What is their names? “ I stood my ground: “I told you, Mom and Dad.” About that time dad pulls up. I don’t know what he said to the guy. The guy went back in his house, and dad told all of us kids it would be better if we just went back home. He never revealed that he was the father of two of the boys. Of course some of the neighbors knew. Never got in trouble for that one. The neighbor was not trying to get us into trouble when she called the police, she was looking out for us.

In the 1960s, research into automotive safety was still relatively new. Late 1960s era cars only had lap belts, meaning that front seat occupants could still bang their heads on the dashboard in a collision. Watch some videos of crash tests and compare the early ones (1960s/early 1970s) to tests on contemporary cars. Those cars were death traps compared to ones manufactured today. Cars manufactured into the 1970s typically had non-power drum brakes that would become unresponsive when they were wet. Late 1960s era cars had carbureted engines without modern emission control systems, and they ran on leaded gasoline. Cars of this vintage and the garages that they were kept in had a distinctive odor; pollution was worse, particularly in places like Los Angeles. Many cities were operating under transportation and city planning models created in the early 1950s; to some degree, this was true into my childhood in the early 1980s. Many cities had scrapped their streetcar, metro, and subway systems (did you know that Rochester, NY once had a subway?). The situation for pedestrians and cyclists was less safe than it is today. Most of the civil rights movement had taken place during the 1960s, but race relations were still very poor in Southern states at the close of the decade. I was once looking through old yearbooks at my high school in Alabama, and I was shocked to see that integration did not take place until the 1970–1971 school year. Also, keep in mind that both Malcolm X and Martin Luther King were assassinated for challenging the Southern status quo. Finally, some really important medical technologies, such as MRI had not yet been invented.

The main difference between the world today and how it was 50 years ago is that people today are made to feel that they are free (atleast psychologically). People today are encouraged to be themselves, and taught that it's okay to be different. Back then, if you were different, you were labelled a delinquent; now the most influential country on earth has made gay marriages legal. Back then, if you were disabled, that was it. Your life was officially over. Now, the word 'disabled' has morphed into the word 'differently abled'. What used to be pitied then is respected now. What used to be looked down upon then is looked up to now. Events that would have prompted social stigma then receive pats on the back now. The world has changed it's opinion of success to include a broader range of achievements, making it possible for a whole lot more people to be labelled successful. Back then, people lived in a conventional world. We now live in an unconventional one:)

Thank you for asking, Steven. My answer echoes earlier ones - those of Dan O’Hanlon and Liam Johnson. Manufactured goods were of much better quality, less plastic involved, less packaging. The internet hadn’t burst upon the scene. Though the net has great benefits, it is now showing a darker side. 50 years ago - 1968 - had its darker side too. It was an unfortunate year in the USA. A synopsis of a book by Mark Kurlansky, "1968, The Year that Rocked the World" : "1968 was a year of political upheaval and protest around the world. In the U.S., there were the assassinations of Robert Kennedy and Martin Luther King, the antiwar protests, the Chicago riot at the Democratic National Convention, and the Apollo 8 mission around the Moon. In Vietnam, the Tet offensive was underway. Protests in France began the downfall of Charles de Gaulle's government. Soviet tanks rolled into Prague to quell the rebellion there. Mexico City police opened fire on university protesters. Mark Kurlansky documents these events and more that occurred in 1968, and examines the cultural forces that drew them altogether across the world." An exceptional year! 1968 is described elsewhere as "a benchmark of unrest, tumult, and change."

I read recently that the government of Columbia and the FARC rebels have signed a peace treaty. With that action there is no actual war in the entire Western Hemisphere. There may be a terrorist action on occasion but one entire half of our world has no war. Americans with African heritage, so called Native Americans and others who have been traditionally discriminated against still have a ways to go but are better off now. The official brutality of places like Selma Alabama, where the authorities beat protestors with truncheons and boards and sicked dogs on ordinary people including women and children, wouldn't be tolerated today. Riots in Ferguson Missouri and Philadelphia? How about Watts for a riot? Look it up. Most blacks won't need to. There were demonstrations seemingly every week. Summer time was riot time. Oh yes, things are better now. (Well, maybe not the music.)

1968, I was five years old and we lived outside of Chicago. My family tried to shield me from the things that were happening around us, but it was all for naught. I was fascinated as a child with all the very colorful people, the hippies, the student protests and the infamous Chicago Democratic Convention that was a bit violent for a convention. Civil Rights had finally come about for all men and women regardless of race, yet racism was everywhere, it was a violent time in Chicago.  1968 in the United States. ... More than 40 people were killed during the month of protest, which led to greater racial tensions between white and black Americans. Despite this, a landmark piece of legislation, the Civil Rights Act of 1968, was passed in April, effectively prohibiting housing discrimination based on race.  The only part I miss of being a child fifty years ago was the fact that I didn’t have any damn bills to pay all the time.  The music had soul back then, I miss that.

I wasn’t yet born. But since my childhood which was a decade later, the quality of childhood itself has changed. Before, children could roam the streets unsupervised. Run to their friends’ home. Bike, swim, play ball outside until the dark. If you were a child and climbed a tree, sometimes way to far. And occasionally you would fall. But most often you would actually learn instead and become stronger. When you found a frog, you could touch the frog, you could put it in a jar and take it home. Everything had a sharp and raw quality. There were germs. There was sweat. And bruises on the knees. You would interact with other small human beings and learn how to communicate, how to be friends or enemies, how to resolve conflict. It was simple. And good.

What aspect of life was better 50 years ago than now? Well I didn't know it at the time but I had at least those (now past) 50 years ahead of me That aspect was better, even though I was not aware of it being such at the time As far as material aspects sure stuff has changed but I can recall complaints be made about a comic book being the ruination of youth “Tails From the Crypt” Biggie now Internet Each period has doom and gloom attached, part of the Complainant Brigade who are not happy unless disaster is just around the corner As per the Life of Brian Always look on the bright side That way when you look back 50 years it will all have been better If you are going through a tough time at the moment try not to dwell on it as again you will want to look back as good times Keep thinking 50 more years to go (at least :) )

1969 Nov 23, Donnell "Spade" Cooley (59) American musician known as the "king of Western swing" prior to his conviction of murder, died of a heart attack following a performance for a police officers benefit concert in Oakland. Cooley's career ended in 1961 when he was arrested and convicted for the brutal murder of his second wife, Ella Mae Evans. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spade_Cooley) 1969 Nov 23, Robin Padilla, Philippine action film star; was born in Manila. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robin_Padilla) 1969 Nov 23, Jonathan Seet, Canadian singer, was born in Singapore. Seet was born to a Singaporean father and an Irish mother who emigrated to Canada shortly after he was born. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonathan_Seet) 1969 Nov 23, The South Tyrolean People's Party (Südtiroler Volkspartei or SVP), founded in 1945 and which had lobbied for more than 20 years for greater autonomy for the German-speaking people of Italy's South Tyrol province, approved the Italian government's proposals to settle the dispute regarding the status of the border region and granting many of the Party's demands. At the urging of SVP leader Silvius Magnago, delegates to the SVP convention voted 583 to 492 to accept the package, paving the way for an agreement between Italy and neighboring Austria. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/November_1969#November_23,_1969_(Sunday))

People were sitting together at night with no phone, no TV.It was easier to meet new people and find your significant other in life, not on mobile.It was easier to buy a house.People were interacting face to face instead social media.People had better sleeping habits.Marrying without swiping right.Less junk food, long live.Life essential things were cheap.Childhood was spending with outdoor games instead of mobile games. Venom!

Thank you for asking my views on this, Steven, Incredibly, 50 years ago was 1969, so my first thought - that radio show presenters were more sensible and not too self-absorbed - had already stopped being quite so widely true by '69. What else, then - traffic jams didn't seem to be quite such a daily problem; motor-fumes not so prevalent, though indeed there was still plenty of coal-smoke; and the greatest days of '60s music were already past; so, on the whole, maybe 50 years isn't quite long enough to go back! Thanks again, Steven - every good wish, Barrie

Here's my short list.  The Civil Rights Movement was a success and racism is gasping its final breathes, LGBT rights are the new Civil Rights struggle and the good guys are winning, amazing progress has been made in medicine, people live longer and healthier lives (60 is the new 40), the Internet has revolutionized modern culture, we can express ourselves and exchange ideas worldwide thru social media, technology has given us affordable conveniences that were science fiction 50 years ago.  It's a great time to be alive.  I wouldn't trade it for any other time.

The world only is. It still remains. It’s hard to say whether it is better. Better for whom or what? :-DAs for development, we have taken long strides forward.And does humanity at large feel better now than 50y ago? Probably, but some things might be worse. Such as sitting too much by a screen of some sort and having to tap on the keyboard and click with the mouse..

I am 66 and lived 50 years ago. Life is a lot better particularly for women. We have a lot more freedom to speak our minds and pursue our own lifestyle. We have instaneous access to information regardless of where we are near a library or not. There is no cold war and fear of nuclear annihilation. We have entertainment other than broadcast tv. If you lived 50 years ago, you would know it is a better place.

Much better. To see how, just imagine yourself taken back to 1966. Tough if you or gay, or a woman, or both. Though less so that 1956, say. No internet, personal computers or mobile phone. You see a global nuclear war as a real possibility. If you are young and in the USA, you need to worry about being sent to the Vietnam War. In the USA and Western Europe, a couple living together are pushing the barriers. Lower income and lower life expectance. Films like Star Wars are 11 years ahead. A lot of what is produced is barely watchable nowadays. The original Star Trek is just starting but will fold after three seasons, with Season Three notably worse. And in much of Europe including the UK, you will see it in black-and-white. Outside the USA, colour television is slow to develop. Britain got its 3rd TV channel in 1964 and Channel 4 is not till 1982. Vinyl records. Videotape becomes available to ordinary people in the early 1970s.

I was a teenager. We did things like have house parties where the "price of admission" was your weight. So, if you weighed 100 pounds, you paid $1.00. The food was good (although probably not the healthiest by today's standards), the music was great -- and no one ever got stabbed or shot. Parents didn't give their kids alcohol or drugs in an effort to be their "friends." We respected adults, even if we didn't agree with them. Gasoline was 33 cents a gallon -- good. Bad -- some of the cars only got 8 miles to the gallon. You knew who your neighbors were. If there were people who lived better than you.....your goal was to work hard so that you could enjoy the same privileges -- not steal from or kill people who had more than you. So many things. The bad -- people could be mean and judgmental against folks who were different them then. That, to me, was the biggest downside. Blacks, LGTQ's, Latinos, women, Asians, Native Americans were all considered second class citizens. And people weren't too fond of Catholics, either. That is what I disliked more than anything.

The other answers are interesting and on point. I will not comment on all the aspects plus or minus but concentrate on one key thing. 50 years ago there was certainly poverty and stratification, but income inequality and the growing gap between high, higher, highest wealth individuals and the rest of the country was not yet structurally institutionalized by changes in the finance industry, tax policy, deregulation, and political and judicial grants of autonomy and authority to corporate entities at the expense of citizens. I do not have rose colored glasses for the past, or a grudge against who we were for our problems and errors, but I do think, overall, this one change has been a huge negative.

The USA team which won the 4 by 400 meters relay in a world record-breaking performance leave the arena, holding aloft clenched fists, at the 1968 Olympic Games in Mexico City, Mexico. Demonstrations, commercial or political, in the Olympic arena are forbidden under the IOC Charter. At the Mexico Games, this was breached by some black US sprinters who after their victories raised a hand covered by a black glove and wore no shoes at the medal ceremony to symbolize the plight of black Americans, some of whom lived in poverty and were denied some human rights. This was not an instant emotive reaction, for Tommie Smith, the winner of the 200 meters, and John Carlos were members of an American organization called the Olympic Project for Human Rights. The IOC indicated that the athletes should be punished and left that to the US Olympic Committee, who expelled them from the team. But others followed their lead. While a rule was broken, the demonstration itself provided a small contribution to another Olympic principle of fighting against any form of discrimination.

This fact can be expressed when you compare the age of any old person to his youth. The planet is getting old n because of the constant overuse of modern industrial technology to feed the rising population, our Worldly resources are depleting n will exhaust soon. Men has got the wrong notion that creating wealth n modern technology is real progress, but spiritually value of life is diminishing every day. We r now just a planet of 7 billion land crawlers who have no idea why they r slogging for 70–80yrs without any purpose.

According to me, 50 years ago. No stress,no internet. They used to respect their parents. They followed their instructions. And spent time with their family members. But there are so many problems they faced but still, i think that was much better. Thankyou! :)

Short answer: no. Long-ish answer: 50 years ago was 1968. There were race riots, Democratic National Convention riots, draft dodging, and hippies. At least two of those are bad. Probably the closest to today’s living that you had 50 years ago was that of “Generic White Nuclear Family” in which chances were you had problems but you weren’t supposed to talk about them in public or private, so it seemed better but really wasn’t. That’s the real basic answer that only covers the social aspect. That doesn’t even come close to covering the health aspect or wealth aspect. And I’m just assuming you’re talking about in the US. So long-ish answer: hell no.

There seemed to have been an unseen but felt structure in place that had a stable syllogism in place that all we had to do was set it up right,to work with one another and nothing could’ve stopped the US….We chose not to do so …. The results are what we see and are experiencing today,…. a virtual balkanization,along the lines of race and politics ,emerging groups claiming sovereignty that have ad hoc to whimsical structures at best,but strong control over media feeds!…. With foreign meddling at its highest point ever,with many social boobytraps and trip wires in place should we try to find our way forward again…. Love it or hate it at least you knew where you stood… Some things had fidelity and it just felt solid back then…not unsure like now

In the 60’s? The belief in the future and the loss of control by religion, previous generations, the state. The world was really going in the right direction. It still is. An immense improvement in the quality of life. Growing middle class. TV, car, dish-washers to everyone. Space travel. Much of the foundation laid for today’s computers. It was the start of the still ongoing sexual revolution, start of the end of discrimination of blacks, women’s rights were starting to be taken seriously. The new personal freedom was echoed by the freedom in the new music streaming through radio, often combined with unheard of lyrics. The 60’s are probably the most important decade in hundreds of years.

The connectivity in society, in other words the sense of neighborhood is all but gone. There are sooo many more people in the world today and developers are stacking people into birdhouse living conditions, whereby people are forced to comingle on top of one other in a very corpoate advantageous plan. We have become, in the western world a me, me isolated existence. A very lonely self gratifying and qualified existence (in many ways), very sad indeed. If it were not for the appreciation of music and participation of some sport, there would be even less connectivity, thank goodness for these 2 disciplines!
The absence of social media and 24 hour news. These two inventions are wrecking self-esteem and driving people’s nervous systems to breaking point.

Well there was a lot less gun violence, so that’s a good thing. The cars of those days were absolutely horrible slow gas guzzling turds with just an AM radio. You couldn’t drive very long because they broke down so much. Houses did not have running water or air conditioning. Life 50 years was much harder than it is today.

The world as we known it is much better then it was 50 years ago, which is around the year 1967. * Men and women are on the same level and they can have the same job opportunities. * The lifespan of today’s world is far longer than it was in the 60’s. * New technology has allowed us to gain information in ways that couldn’t have been possible in the 60’s * Racism has been dying down recently, schools and workplaces have great diversity in terms of people.

In a word: quality. (Of that is, manufactured goods.) When you bought something, it lasted—so much so, that when and if it did break down it coulee taken somwhere and repaired. With the digital revolution, tolerances have been pared down to next to zero—timed to break down (and be thrown away) a week after the guarantee expires. Plastics: I miss the days of them waxed-paper carton and waxed-paper straws. Indeed, the days of waxed paper (instead of Saran Wrap. NINETY-FIVE percent of the plastics manufactured are unnecessary—and look what it’s doing to the Earth.

I don’t know. We had shorter life expectancy but more clarity of thinking. Instead of information making us more intelligent, we’re now much more lazy and distracted. In the past(I’m talking 90s and early 2000s), TVs and PCs were confined to particular places. But now, gossip is carried in your pockets. I would say that while we didn’t know as much, we led more fulfilling lives for it.

Steven, it was easier to ‘savor’ life as it unfolded 50 years ago than it is today. Today, things move so fast that it almost takes your breath away. There is no time to just relax and enjoy what is unfolding. Instead it seems you are caught in the turmoil with little thought of really enjoying it.

I believe it is Think of all the technical advances from 50 years ago not to mention the social change in race relations that have vastly improved even if we haven't finished the job. Yeah, much better I think, when we speak of the good ole days, a lot of really bad stuff gets swept under the rug.

Well it depends on where you live. Middle East was pretty peaceful before Soviet intervention. US doesn’t hate Arabs that much because no 9/11. And no Chernobyl yet, good for Ukrainians and Belarusians. People are so peaceful, at least in the US. No rough Putin, but kissing Brezhnev. No war between Argentina and GB.
facilities and services are no longer segregated by color.

The streets were more safer than it is now; you could sleep with windows and doors open without feeling scared. Young girls could jog or go for a walk without being mugged and then murdered. Children would be safe without being kidnapped and later on murdered.
Better technology, medicine, mass communication, mass media, social mobility, education, sanitation, infrastructure, trade . . .

People actually spoke to and interacted with other people rather than be a zombie looking at their smartphone all day. Excessive smartphone use by society makes me sick to my stomach. I use it in moderation and don’t use it to avoid others unless of course I’m in a bad negative mood.
Advances in medicine, information technology, agriculture… The list is too long. Perhaps a better question is what about life 50 years ago was better than today?

Of course it is. The Soviet Union fell and the countries of East Europe are now free. Even the Russians themselves are free, except they don’t seem to like it. These are all great improvements. There is more violence in the Middle East and Africa. But I think that the spread of violent Islam is itself a consequence of decolonization in the West and Soviet scheming to inject Socialism in the developing world. Hopefully, that will work itself out.

Alhamdulillah, these days Islam has become more widely spread than 50 years ago. Being from the former Soviet Union, I remember that before its collapse in 1991, there had been very little, if anything, in terms of Islamic practice, at least in my childhood.

It depends on the glasses one wears to see the world. Change is the only permanent thing. The world will keep on changing with time. We have to accept the world as it is without having any iota of doubt about its being the best or otherwise. There is no gain in lamenting that the world was better 50 years ago.

Magic for this 11 year old kid, freedom, virtually no crime and greed (NZ social democracy), free medical care inc. dental and education right up to post Grad. Excellent food as we had very little over processed muck and NO chain take outs. Please send me back…!
No
1st Earth Day on 4/22/1970.
